key_title: Key to the subspecies of Chrysocephalum apiculatum

source.author: Wilson, P.G.
source.title: A taxonomic treatment of Chrysocephalum apiculatum and C. semipapposum (Asteraceae: Gnaphlieae)
source.citation: From: Wilson, P.G. (2016). A taxonomic treatment of Chrysocephalum apiculatum and C. semipapposum (Asteraceae: Gnaphlieae). Nuytsia 27:33-73.

leads.lead_text: Leaves with sessile and glandular stipitate hairs; female florets with 4–9 pappus bristles
Leaves glandular-puberulous and with minute sessile glands; female florets with 0–3 pappus bristles; Western Victoria
Leaves linear to oblong-obovate, often curved, tomentose; female florets with 4–9 pappus bristles; Mallee
Leaves narrowly oblong, acute, glandular-stipitate and sparsely cottony; female florets with (3–)4–7 pappus bristles; East Gippsland
Stems silky with strongly appressed silvery hair
Stems cottony; leaves cobwebbed, cottony or silky; female florets with 4 or 5 pappus bristles; coastal areas
Stems and leaves cobwebbed; female florets with 0–6 shortly plumose pappus bristles
Leaves linear to narrowly oblong or narrowly obovate, with cottony hairs
Leaves filiform to linear, with silky hairs
Mid-stem leaves entire, flat; capitula congested; female florets with 0–4 pappus bristles
Mid-stem leaves with recurved margins and somewhat undulate; capitula in small corymbs; female florets with 0 or 1 pappus bristles
Leaves filiform, silky; capitula 1–5, in compact terminal clusters; female florets with 1 or 2 pappus bristles
Leaves filiform to linear, silky, becoming glabrous with age; capitula solitary or in a compact orbicular cyme; female florets with 5 or 6 pappus bristles
